With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is a normal part of this industry, which fits well with a free-market global economy. However, free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of scarce metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the prices of raw materials are going down. When considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these low raw material prices.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To explore the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your accommodation, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available. You can also rent boats if you prefer to explore on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is known as 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reasons. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles, looking like a string of pearls. At night, the lights from the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly, adding to the beauty of the area.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK’s First Workshop**
You can join a course at the Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, where you can build your own bike. You will get a custom-designed frame and enjoy a fun weekend of bike-building. 
It’s Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The only sounds are from machines in the Bamboo Bike Club, the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bamboo bikes. I’m here to see what’s happening. There is a lot of energy and excitement in the air. 
Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike construction. Companies like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire have brought back this method, which has been around since 1894. However, many cyclists find bamboo bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost around $2,995 or £1,868. This high price is what motivated James and Ian to spend years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales. They wanted to create a bamboo bike business that was affordable for regular cyclists. 
After a lot of research, they realized they didn’t just want to sell bike frames. They wanted to share the joy of making something unique and sustainable. This led to the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more about community than business. Both James and Ian have full-time jobs; James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. 
They offer monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a reasonable price. On the first day, they teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You start by gluing the bamboo tubes together to form the bike frame. They also use metal tubes for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. 
For someone like me, who is not very good at DIY, this can be challenging. James and Ian are always there to help, checking every cut and joint. They encourage everyone, saying it’s okay to make mistakes. If you mess up, just try again with a new piece of bamboo. 
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp bindings and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and any personal touches. 
James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are just as strong as metal ones. Ian has been riding his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it. They use thicker tubes and bindings to make the bikes even stronger. 
While bamboo bikes may not look as polished as professional ones, they are unique. I think these bikes are great for relaxed rides rather than racing. I choose a 'Classic English' frame for a comfortable ride. 
I take James’s bike for a test ride, and it feels light and smooth, thanks to bamboo’s ability to absorb bumps. James says the real joy comes when you ride the bike. They are very light and fun to ride. 
And the best part? The price is less than £500.

**Self-Help Books**
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She immediately thought it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very successful, and Diane started her own company. Dr. Gray's book, which helps people communicate better between genders, is a key part of a growing self-help industry. This industry tries to meet many of Americans' desires for improvement, but it also creates new desires and supports the publishing world in New York. 
In Britain, people are discovering that this genre can produce many books that are not very good, but there are even worse ones. For every self-help book published, many others are rejected because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. As new editors search for the next big hit, the quality of writing is often not a priority. What matters most is how marketable the book is. Diane Reverend lists important questions like: "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" She admits that a catchy title can make a big difference in attracting readers.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement between the writer and the reader that the truth will be told. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too shameful or not important enough. Sometimes, they might invent stories that express their truth better than sticking strictly to the facts. They may even label their work as an autobiography just to make readers believe it is true, even if it is mostly fiction. This can happen without any intention to deceive.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Scholars have studied detective stories and believe they reflect the social conflicts of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. These stories often symbolize deeper human desires like lust or greed, and their resolutions show how society can return to order. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt, and the characters often represent different sides of the same personality. The private detective and the criminal understand each other and share a strange connection. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. His mission is complicated by his feelings of guilt and his desire for justice.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is considered one of the best science writers today. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. Neither of us felt comfortable in such a fancy place. Gould believes that to write well about science, you need to understand the scientific community. If you don’t know its rules, you will struggle. One of his key beliefs is to never talk down to the reader. He advises, "You can simplify the language but must never change the main idea. If readers feel you are treating them like children, they will lose interest."

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers during lunch, the air is very cold. To handle this summer's high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels like being in the Arctic. This shows how people often misuse air-conditioning today. It has become a common part of our lives, showing how we can control the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and release it at night. These ideas may seem simple, but they can make a big difference and reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are becoming more interested in sundials, which are tools that measure time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, sundials were important for keeping time accurately. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just decorative items in gardens. Now, they are being taken seriously again. David Harber, a maker of sundials, believes their charm comes from their connection to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts to work after he delivers it. Sundials are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago, where serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on teacups. It was fascinating to watch them, as each brushstroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners have any natural talent? However, the atmosphere in the class was friendly and relaxed. Everyone was there to enjoy themselves, and even the teacher did not want to paint as quickly and perfectly as I had remembered.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport, twelve nights in Venice, the beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book, the clerk told them that the other travelers were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks, and then more drinks. 
When they landed, a heavy woman with glasses told them, "The coach will take us on. Stay together now." The brochure didn’t mention an overnight stop, but when the coach arrived at its destination, Keith realized that was what was happening. It was close to midnight, and tired from traveling, they didn’t question the beds they were offered. But the next morning, when they found out they were supposed to stay there for their holiday, they became worried.
"The lake and the water birds are here," the receptionist said with a smile. "You can take a boat to Interlaken." 
Keith calmly told the man, "There has been a mistake. We were supposed to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." 
"I don’t know that name, sir. This is Switzerland," the receptionist replied. 
"A coach is supposed to take us on. An official said so on the plane," Keith insisted. 
"Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. If you want to change now—" 
"We haven’t changed our minds. There’s been a mistake," Keith said firmly. The receptionist shook his head, saying he didn’t know about any mistake. 
Dawne added, "The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She mentioned the travel agency in London. 
"Is there a problem?" a woman said cheerfully. She was the same heavy woman Keith had seen at Gatwick. 
"My name is Franks," she said. "I’m married to the man with the bad leg." 
"Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks?" Dawne asked. "We’re in the wrong hotel." 
Again, Dawne described the travel agency and the bald clerk. Keith interrupted, "It seems we got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left everything to her." 
"We should have known when they weren’t from Dover," Dawne added, mentioning they heard them talking about Darlington. Keith wished she would let him speak. 
"We noticed you at Gatwick," Keith said. "We knew you were in charge." 
"I counted you, but you probably didn’t see me," Mrs. Franks replied. "Let me explain. Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends clients to many places, with different holidays at different prices. There are villa holidays for young people, treks to Turkey, and treks for singles to the Himalayas." 
"What I’m trying to say is that all tickets and labels look similar, yellow with two red bands," Mrs. Franks laughed. "If you just followed others with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up anywhere!" 
"But we’re not supposed to be in Switzerland," Keith insisted. 
"Let’s see," Mrs. Franks said suddenly and walked away, leaving them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. 
"She seems nice," Dawne whispered. Keith wasn’t listening. He was trying to remember everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and then the girl leading them to the plane. 
"Nice to have some young people here," an old man said. He and his wife looked like they were in their eighties. They had slept well, thanks to the fresh air by the lake. 
"That’s nice," Dawne replied. Keith walked out of the reception area, and Dawne followed him. Outside the hotel, they didn’t say anything about the irony of their situation. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they had ended up on a package tour with elderly people when they wanted to escape from the needs of older people. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to convince him to join them.

**HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON**
American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports.
Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal described Shackleton as "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is an exaggeration. Now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Many biographies and stories about his famous voyage on the Endurance are being published, and the American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition. Columbia Tristar is also making a film about Shackleton's life.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his leadership and communication skills and often refer to each other as "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become an example for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for years. His firm focuses on communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises.
MacGregor explains that even if a company handles a crisis well, poor communication can still cause problems. He believes Shackleton is a great management model because he had strong values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, including their lives. One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed his commitment to the safety of his men.
In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary when his ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all eventually reach safety if you do your best and trust me." Throughout the ordeal, it was clear that Shackleton was always in control.
MacGregor notes that Shackleton planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and valued their opinions. He was flexible and willing to change plans if something was not working. Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, endurance, and patience. MacGregor points out that in difficult times, especially in America, people often want quick solutions. However, sometimes it is better to wait and see how things develop.
Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he noticed the expedition photographer, Hurley, without gloves. Shackleton insisted that Hurley wear his gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn’t. He also once offered a biscuit to a starving crew member, saying it was too valuable to leave behind.
As Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says, "The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton represents the ideals we long for today."

**Tapping into a Food Supply**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a unique primate called the aye-aye. Its way of finding food is similar to that of a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker search for insect larvae by digging into wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. In contrast, the aye-aye uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and scoop out the insects.
Although scientists first described the aye-aye's unusual feeding method over a hundred years ago, they have only recently learned how it finds the insects hidden in the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle.
Dr. Erickson wanted to see if the aye-ayes could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might have entered to lay eggs. He gave them logs with narrow holes, some leading to food and others that were empty. The aye-ayes quickly went for the logs with food, showing they did not need to rely on visual signs. They might have been using their sense of smell or hearing, but further tests showed they did not need these senses either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked and when the insects were dead and silent.
So, how did the aye-ayes find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that they could sense the cavities in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. Dr. Erickson believes the aye-aye uses a method called echo-location, where it listens for sounds that tell it there is a hollow space below. It can also hear insects moving when they are disturbed by the tapping.
The idea that the aye-aye fills the role of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting. However, there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood, so the woodpecker role may not be empty. The aye-aye is not only similar to a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat, but it also acts like a squirrel. Its front teeth grow continuously, just like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild chewing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat inside.

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us really know what their lives were like when they were young? The few diaries we find often do not tell the whole story, and family stories are often only partly remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write down our stories but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but these are still just images. 
Hannah Renier has found a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with illustrations if needed. Her focus is on ordinary people, not famous ones. The idea came to her when she spoke with her family and realized how much of the past was being forgotten. 
"When I started, I didn’t take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I met people who really wanted to share their interesting lives. They often say they are doing it for their children or for future generations, but they enjoy the process too." 
The promise of confidentiality helps her subjects feel comfortable sharing their stories. One 62-year-old man, who has experienced both success and failure in his life, said, "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful memories, like my divorce." He wrote his story for his family but hasn’t let his adult children read it yet because he feels they might be hurt by some details. He thinks it might be better for them to read it after he is gone. 
Hannah has noticed that many people are influenced by their childhood experiences. "It’s amazing how much people are shaped by their parents," she says. "The things they learned as children can affect them for the rest of their lives. They often repeat the same patterns in their relationships." 
Many people still feel regret or resentment about unresolved issues with their parents, even many years later. They may try to impress a parent who never seemed impressed, or they might rebel against their parents’ expectations. 
Hannah acts as a recorder rather than a questioner. "I’m not there to pry into their lives," she explains. People sometimes share things and then worry if they should be included in the book. She tells them they can remove anything when they see the draft, but most people want to be honest about their lives. 
This is not about vanity; it’s not just people wanting to show off their interesting lives. In our fast-paced world, we often forget our past. Hannah’s work helps people connect with their roots and gives them a sense of immortality. 
Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Hannah uses to write the life story, organizing the events and interpreting them. Modern technology helps her create everything except the binding, which has gold lettering. Clients can choose the color and title of their book. 
The final product is well-organized and written, reflecting the life of the person it is about. Each book costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies available for £25 each. Hannah receives about 10 inquiries a week, but the high cost stops many people from going ahead. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she says. "But the people I’ve worked with are often from wealthy backgrounds, the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted in the past."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculptures in the world, with over six hundred pieces. It is important to note that none of the sculptures are original; they are all replicas made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is located in a specially designed gallery with great natural light. There are many benefits to having plaster casts: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together again. You can view almost all the famous works of Greek and Roman sculpture in just one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center that has community darkrooms and a gallery with various photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (ages 12 to 16) through our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and provide a full range of photographic materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and parts of the world. It also contains Britain's oldest complete geological collection, created by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection has nearly 10,000 rare specimens stored in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collection during his life, making it an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, allowing visitors to see the major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with clear labels explaining their nature and modern uses.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The University uses its own aircraft based at Cambridge Airport to take photographs across Great Britain. These photographs are interesting as they provide a detailed record of the landscape, showing both the natural environment and human impact from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can help with any questions. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can usually be purchased, which take about a month to prepare.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world, making it a unique tourist attraction. Visitors can enjoy creating wall hangings by rubbing over one of more than a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center has made resin copies, called facsimiles, to preserve the originals while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. These brass plates were used as memorials and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, with the widest range available at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I feel lucky to have spent 35 years with small children, and I have loved every moment. This morning, I enjoyed feeding my baby, which is what being a father means to me. I am very fortunate with my children; we all share a love for opera, theatre, books, and music. This has created a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in physical punishment. I have slapped my children in anger before, but I do not support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I am available if they need me, but I believe they should reach out to me first. I do not want to make them feel guilty for not contacting me, as my parents did to me.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was quite young, around 25, when my children were born, and I found the responsibilities difficult at times. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I appreciate. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which helped me stay connected to the world. I missed some important moments, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on holidays to places like the south of France, and they enjoy spending time with my friends and attending parties and award ceremonies without feeling out of place. I think my job is seen as exciting, which has helped our relationship.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just as I was starting my political career. My wife and I promised to make time for our children, but as my political work increased, finding time became difficult. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if my children can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am disappearing from their lives. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their children to work, which shows that we are becoming more aware of the importance of including our kids in our lives.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, which made me think more about fatherhood. I worked hard to stay connected with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while, so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I wonder if I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my children like adults too soon. Kate recently said that I was too lenient. I wish I had set more rules and structure. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as I do about my youngest. In that way, being a parent never really ends.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for children when I turned 30. I had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new furniture?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. Creating a child feels very special, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but a single smile from her can make all my irritation disappear. A baby's smile is incredibly powerful and can soften anyone's heart.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's ten-act play about a powerful warrior can feel long, but Terry Hands' production makes it one of the most exciting nights of the year. He has cut parts of the text and created a show that combines the beauty of Marlowe's writing with fast-paced action. Antony Sher shines in the lead role, performing impressive stunts and capturing the audience's full attention with his intense desire for power. Great performance!  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, which was first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second act, the story shifts and becomes a deep and moving look at the effects of illness. Wall was a talented writer who sadly passed away at just 44 years old.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is the latest Irish playwright to enrich the English stage. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one looks at the decline of the fishing industry with strong characters, deep emotions, and moments of humor. The play sometimes feels a bit aimless, but it builds up to an exciting ending.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This traditional thriller involves a "perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play crime writers who plan to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, the twists are cleverly done.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes finds the humor in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. After a successful run at the Swan Theatre, the show is now on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce giving great performances as the trio of tricksters.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society is now in London after its success at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This charming new musical by playwright Alan Ayckbourn reimagines the Beauty and the Beast story in a London suburb. With a beautiful score by John Pattison and a celebration of romantic love, this show is sure to be a hit. London producers should take notice!  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy almost received a negative review, but it is saved by strong performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Unfortunately, many other actors seem uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. The story is about a seemingly respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son, resulting in a wonderful play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a suspicious bookshop. She discovers that one of the few customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to separate her from her friends, who are well-developed characters in the story. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes darker and more intense. Her time trapped in the cellar of an old house is described in a powerful way. This book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It is an important and convincing read.
**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack, who comes from a poor background, and Rill, who attends a fancy girls' school, team up when they find out that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915 that killed eight people. Different perspectives and documents like maps and personal accounts help the reader understand the event, making them work hard to uncover the truth. This is a clever and complex novel that requires careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer feels out of place in her family and the male-dominated society of the 1930s. She loves her father's racing pigeons and takes care of them when he leaves for work, even though her mother is stressed and unhappy. This engaging story teaches that "There are different kinds of cleverness," which is a positive message. Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.
**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
In this chilling story, Robert Westall tells the tale from the perspective of a mature woman named Rose. She moves with her two children to a cottage owned by Sepp Yaxley to escape her materialistic life and her arrogant husband. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why Yaxley disappeared, but their presence causes local people to become hostile, putting their lives in danger. By the end, while the violence is controlled, Rose is troubled by her son's cold behavior. The story is very gripping.
**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam is a chubby, talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a wealthy family. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. Although the story moves slowly at times, it has gentle humor and shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It appeals to both boys and girls, which is rare.
**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, vividly describing his New Zealand setting and creating a likable narrator named Robbie. Robbie takes a job gardening for an elderly man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is disturbed by what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them. The story takes a thrilling turn while still providing deep insights into character and relationships. It is unusual and compelling.
**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a painful and sad story about Mick, who struggles with personal relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. He learns to deal with the negative expectations of others and his low self-esteem through a role in a school play and the support of a caring first-year teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a very emotional read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are using weightlessness to test their ideas. The aircraft looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964 and based on the Boeing 707 passenger plane. However, inside, it was very different. The interior was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, leaving just a few at the back where the nervous students sat.
For a year, these students had competed to take part in this flight, which was organized by the European Space Agency. They had to come up with creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas won a spot on this unique flight, which was like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride. 
For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that felt like a giant bird soaring up and then diving down. The pilot would cut the engines at 3,000 meters, allowing the plane to rise higher for a moment before gravity pulled it back down. During the few seconds between rising and falling, everything inside the aircraft became weightless, and the students would feel as if they were closer to the moon than to Earth.
The flight took off smoothly, but any thoughts of a regular passenger flight disappeared when the pilot put the plane into a steep climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and we felt the blood rush from our heads as we were pushed against the cabin floor. Then, the engines stopped, and we quickly experienced weightlessness. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. One small step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We floated around, confused about where to go, as up and down lost their meaning.
After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. The return of gravity was sudden, and some students landed hard. After the first curve, some students felt sick at the thought of the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave us ten minutes of "space time" for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to find out how cats always land on their feet. They released a device they built to investigate this, and one student managed to turn it over using a remote control. 
Another student almost landed on it during a rough return to gravity. Meanwhile, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joints are affected by the lack of gravity, which could help in building future space stations. A team from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They believe that once perfected, these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind.
After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This experience would stay with us for a long time. One student said, "It was unforgettable. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 
I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t experience any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which was actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which I enjoyed because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can take the time to plant trees, then you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is special because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is suitable for planting trees. I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me, and I was eager to start. My family became enthusiastic as we went along. 
I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres. In New Zealand in 1968, it was a very rainy winter. It’s funny to think of that time as happy because it rained almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been wetter or colder for such a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for the next planting session. I would come out of the Land Rover, still warm and dry, but then the rain would start, and my jacket was still damp from the day before. My boots were soaked, and my hands struggled with slippery laces. 
During that first year, I had a helper who was an experienced tree-planter, which was very useful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck, filling it with as many trees as you can. When the bag is full, it’s heavy and difficult to carry, but it gets easier as it gets lighter. The hardest part of the job was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you set up three poles in a straight line. These poles help you keep your planting straight. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down, turn around, and come back. 
I enjoy hard physical work, and it helped me get fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get into a rhythm and use the fewest movements needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You train your body to do the same movements, making it much easier. You develop a regular process: taking the tree out of the bag, digging a hole, putting it in the ground, stamping it down, and moving on. 
Mentally, it was interesting. My mind started to wander, and I had many thoughts about life and nature. A lot of my ideas about the natural world began during those days. I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which has been very satisfying. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me anxious. However, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy. 
I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months by myself. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I would write; in the afternoons, I would prune the trees, and in the evenings, I would do research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth. It is a powerful connection.

**Bringing Up Badgers**
"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have run an open dairy farm in Somerset for six years, and we are known for caring for orphaned animals. But the strange noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—caught my attention. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were covered in fleas, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badgers are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground. If they are orphaned, they usually die from hunger and are never found. 
These three cubs were brought to me by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while laying drain pipes. Their mother was found dead, with her babies still trying to suckle. I could see the cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove for warmth. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth first to mimic their mother’s licking. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started moving around, although a bit unsteadily. They were happy together, with a heated pad to keep them warm.
However, three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, even though he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding animals, it’s important not to let them drink too quickly, as liquid can go into their lungs. In Willow’s case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, especially for such a small cub. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other two.
Then, six days later, a local farmer came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew she wouldn’t return because the area was too disturbed, and the cub was cold and hungry. I named him Willow II. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon discovered that he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to chew and eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more variety.
At nearly five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Normally, badgers eat 60% earthworms, along with beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and even plant roots. My badgers were better off than others that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms. By August, the cubs started to become nocturnal, going for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they would get excited and chase each other’s tails. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and ended up with bruises.
During these late-night walks, I noticed other badgers in our field. They were likely looking for food because their own territories were not providing enough. Badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive towards others. We were warned that they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help build a home for them on our farm. With advice from others, we designed a new sett for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate that faced their usual walking path. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside.
As the sett was built, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became more interested in the tunnels and their bedding than in walking. The cost of building was higher than we expected, but a local bus company called Badgerline helped fund part of it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a proper home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle down. Half an hour later, I returned to find three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep.
Now, my walks with them are less frequent, especially since they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only occasionally because she has joined a nearby sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to greet me before running off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

**In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, during his time, one of his most important achievements was mapping the "variations of the compass." These variations, now called "declination," refer to the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Understanding this was crucial for sailors to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans accurately.
Halley was one of only two people in England paid to do scientific research at that time. He set out for the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic, but his first trip was cut short due to problems with the crew. He later made a second voyage that took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From this journey, he published a chart in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This chart helped sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the route of Halley's ship, the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 to start this project, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley led a remarkable life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and worked on other projects."
During his career, Halley invented a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton while he wrote *Principia Mathematica*, a key work in physics. Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements similar to Halley's but with more advanced tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.
Dr. Clark explains, "We usually measure the strength of the magnetic field, but not its direction. To measure direction, we need to know true north." On this expedition, they will use global positioning satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the project. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean.
Halley's journey was significant because it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. 
Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to succeed in this journey? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
Does he share Halley's passion? "I am ready to dedicate eight months to this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**Power Dressing**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior puzzles scientists, including Charles Darwin, who wondered how such a showy feature could have evolved in a world where survival is tough. Darwin believed that animals evolve through natural selection, meaning that the strongest and best-adapted individuals survive and reproduce. However, he thought that peacocks' tails were a burden rather than an advantage, so he introduced the idea of "sexual selection," suggesting that females are attracted to beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed with him. He believed that if peahens prefer males with the most impressive tails, there must be a reason beyond just beauty. Wallace thought that the tail might signal some hidden quality that helps the males survive.
Now, over a century later, researchers like Marion Petrie are studying peafowl at Whipsnade to answer two main questions: Do peahens really choose the males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have any real advantages, or is it just for show?
The researchers have observed that the hens do seem to prefer the males with the most eye spots on their tails, which are related to the tail's length. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways. William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and free from parasites, and their bright feathers could indicate this. However, Petrie and her team have not yet been able to test this idea with the peacocks at Whipsnade.
This year, Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive males with those of less attractive ones to see if the children of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that the females' choice is practical.
There is also an interesting theory from the mathematician R.A. Fisher, known as "Fisher's Runaway." He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that tail, and her daughters will inherit her preference for long tails. Over generations, this could lead to even longer tails, as males with the longest tails attract more mates. This process could explain how such extravagant tails evolved, and it would also support Darwin's idea that females might eventually choose beauty for its own sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He has done this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is filled with beautiful yachts that have the latest technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although she was designed last year, she looks like she is 100 years old, which might make people think her owner is a romantic. Maybe I am, but I’m not sure.
My boat uses the best parts of traditional boat design, but modern technology has made it easier to build. However, it is important to note that advanced technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going sailing in the first place. I am not saying that sailors should go back to suffering through every difficulty. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if every sail does the work by itself? Dealing with a sail that flaps in the wind is part of being a sailor.
Also, why should we change the steering position from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less safe spot in the middle? This change often makes the cabin feel like a big ship, with a bed larger than what we have at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my earlier boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race, the previous owner said she had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over time, I learned how true this was. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics for navigation, yet she was the easiest boat I ever sailed.
However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I realized I could no longer keep her. I looked for a younger boat but found nothing suitable, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although the designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, use computer design programs, Irens first sketched the boat on a paper napkin and then moved to the computer. After creating a model, just like boat builders did in the past, we worked together to improve the design. The final version was perfect.
The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the water, and has a peaceful atmosphere inside, much of which is made from reclaimed pitch pine. This calmness may be because she was designed purely as a sailing boat, without thinking about any furniture. This traditional method works well. The Westerman shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it is wise to learn from history. Built with special treated wood, she is completely waterproof. So, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but still looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences. Genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This means that the things that make us different from animals are very recent changes. Our biological history suggests that our ability to create art and other unique human traits come from just a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.
Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, using different sounds to warn about predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. This means that besides art, there are not many clear differences between humans and animals.
If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. We only have clear evidence of human art from around 35,000 years ago, with famous cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent burst of creativity makes us different, we need to consider how our art is different from animal art. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is made for enjoyment, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas to others, this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong serves clear purposes, like defending territory or attracting a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. By this measure, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during the breeding season, suggesting they do not sing just for enjoyment. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third difference is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris, and people can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.
Human art styles change quickly. For example, Roman authors wrote about geese honking 2,000 years ago, and they still do today. However, human art evolves so fast that even casual museum visitors can tell a twentieth-century painting from older works like the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when and who painted a work, but they might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy. In reality, these artists were chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day and was upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot claim.
These chimpanzee paintings blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the ape paintings were not created for practical purposes; they were made for the satisfaction of the painter. Some might argue that human art is different because it is often meant to communicate with others, while the apes did not care about sharing their art. However, this argument is not very strong, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction.

'Life was Getting Out of Hand'**
Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy manual work again. Many people love technology because it provides us with amazing devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, this belief has made us think that technology is the best way to live. Using our hands for tasks does not harm the environment, unlike some gadgets.
Recently, Susan had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix. This made her question whether we really need all these gadgets. She started to let go of some household technology as it broke down. This made her wonder what "free time" really means. Does it just mean we have more time to buy and use more gadgets? She feels that marketing tricks us into thinking we need them.
When her word processor started making strange noises, she decided to leave it outside, where it now sits quietly. She enjoys working with her hands instead of being tied to noisy machines. She can take her sewing projects anywhere, which she loves. 
There are some gadgets she appreciates, like her washing machine, which she found very useful after a year without one. However, she discovered joy in giving up others. For example, they returned their rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped them spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies. 
Susan has taken up sewing by hand since her old sewing machine is now just a table for plants. She realized that people often think they cannot live without technology, but she finds pleasure in doing things manually. Computers do many tasks for us, but she enjoys the calmness of sewing and the satisfaction of creating something with her hands. 
Now, she can listen to the radio or talk with family while sewing. If the task is simple, she can even watch her favorite TV shows without feeling guilty because she is also being productive. She enjoys the cozy feeling of sewing by the fire with a cup of tea.
At first, she thought sewing by hand was tedious and tiring, but she now finds it relaxing and rewarding. She feels that things get done quickly, and life slows down to a more enjoyable pace. She also appreciates washing dishes by hand, which allows her to daydream.
This reflection has made her reconsider what appliances she really needs in her home. She wonders if they truly need a freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. In fact, she thinks they could save a lot of money by living without electric lights!

**The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst: A Profile**
Charles Hurst is a skilled cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop located under a railway arch in East London. When she arrives, he greets her quickly and seems to be in a hurry. It’s not clear if he is always this way or if he is just shy. The workshop is busy, filled with unfinished furniture and wooden planks in many natural colors.
Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a great reputation. His schedule is always full for months ahead, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right choice. While it is easy to find furniture-makers, it is harder to find one who focuses on making high-quality furniture with simple designs. Hurst notes that there are not many true cabinet-makers left, as many people call themselves furniture-makers instead.
Hurst is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He criticizes mass-produced items and craftsmen who make poor-quality pieces. His desire for perfection is a big part of his success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills, saying, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." Although he shows some modesty at the end of the interview, he clearly believes in his abilities.
Hurst learned his craft on his own by asking questions and observing. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return to him for more projects. He enjoys working on entire houses for clients. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients are unsure of what they want, but he appreciates those who have clear ideas.
Despite his confidence, Hurst respects other craftsmen and acknowledges that some are better than him. He mentions that he was not trained at Parnham, a top furniture design school. He is critical of craftsmen who take too long to make one piece and of students who focus on making fashion statements instead of practical furniture. Hurst believes that furniture should be useful, not just a statement.
In the end, Hurst shows a humble attitude about his work. He reminds us that, "After all, I am only making furniture," as he bids farewell.

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and help us feel better.
The second theory focuses on learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.
The third theory is about energy. It suggests that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted rules of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most people have their own quirks and strange habits. For example, someone might love entering newspaper competitions, collect beer mats, or write angry letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism is the desire to be unique, while conformity is the desire to fit in with others. For many people, the need to be accepted and liked by others is stronger than the desire to stand out and be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests, which others might see as strange. Being part of a group can be comforting. Most of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be ourselves. Even when we follow the crowd, we may feel the need to show our individuality. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as I am."
At any time, we can choose to express our individuality. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, the American singer, once said that when you truly believe in what you are doing and pursue it with determination, you may confuse others. However, this strong expression of individuality is not the same as eccentricity at first. If a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric.
The key to eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be strange; they simply are. A true eccentric does not care much about what others think. They act according to their true selves, which makes them different from enthusiasts, pranksters, clever criminals, show-offs, and recluses. These people are aware of society and often act in response to it. Some want to impress others, while others want to escape from society. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives freely, without concern for how others see them.

**Natural Books**

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet many important figures in this field. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and enjoyable for anyone who loves nature.
