**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five important British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers often feel okay about bad reviews. They believe that any mention of a book can help sales, as readers want to form their own opinions. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own feelings about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago. However, there is still a problem with the lack of attention given to paperbacks. Weekly reviews often do not cover enough books, and original paperbacks rarely get serious reviews. Still, publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and an author. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several positive reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. Without them, we would struggle to promote our books, especially since we often do not publish well-known authors and do not spend much on advertising. Positive reviews are much more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. The impact of reviews on sales is complex. Good reviews can help launch a book and a writer's career, but they need support from other factors like recommendations from readers and effective marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the U.S., a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, bookshops often ignore reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of great reviews for people to notice a good writer. Interestingly, some poorly reviewed books become bestsellers. The situation is unpredictable, but non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than on the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they really help sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people paid attention. Today, it can also be the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that dates back to ancient Egypt. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something unique that reflects the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's work is very different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. He realized that there were endless possibilities for designs. So, he decided to focus on making weathervanes.
Before starting this business, Graham trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Five years ago, he and his wife, Liz, switched roles: she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow his business. He has no regrets about this change. He says, "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic. I really enjoy designing."
Graham has created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs available because they are still popular. Graham believes that people like handmade items because they want something different.
He does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. He feels he has found his place in the market. People appreciate the uniqueness of his work, and he enjoys seeing a simple shape turn into something almost lifelike. 
For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction. Nowadays, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add a special touch to their homes. This trend has helped crafts like Graham's. He is now busier than ever, sending flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world, especially in America and Denmark. He explains that the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, suddenly fell apart. He felt disappointed and worried because it had been two years since he earned any money, and he was struggling to pay his bills.
A sensible person in Evans' situation would have found a job. He could have returned to his previous work in television or started a new project. Instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching for his first novel. Although it was a risky decision, he had been thinking about the story for a while. He was inspired by a farrier he met while visiting a friend in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive. The owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people were called "horse whisperers." 
Evans became very interested in this idea. He initially wanted to write a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after losing the film project, he decided to write the story as a book. During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later reflected, "It was a strange time. I was observing people, but I felt alone and worried about my life falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and unsure how to support my family."
By the end of August, after returning home, he had written the first half of the book. He was still under pressure from the bank and needed to know if he should continue. He bravely showed his work to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for more feedback, he suggested that Evans might receive $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some of his debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left. 
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with a 12-page summary of the rest of the book, to seven UK publishers just before they went to the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "What?" The agent replied, "It's okay, I feel something big is happening."
What happened next became a famous story in publishing. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans and his team were amazed. They had not even sent the manuscript to New York, and they still do not know how it got there. They also did not send it to Hollywood, but soon major film studios were interested in it. 
Evans' UK agent worked with an American agent, who called to say, "I think we can get $3 million for the film rights." They all laughed in disbelief. They decided that each studio should present their ideas to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called him one after the other, asking to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel.
Evans shared this story while we enjoyed coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It has all felt like a fairy tale so far. I don’t want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very challenging, and I don’t want to become just an employee of the people who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll bring in someone else now.'"
He wants to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to make that film anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to the world of chess. Chess has become more of a young man's game. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. He won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now, at 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time, or they lose the game. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This increased pressure favors younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30.
The way chess is played has also changed. Much of it now happens off the board. Players must prepare seriously before matches, especially because computers have changed the game. A small computer can store one million chess games and provide quick access to many games of an opponent. In recent matches, players have used large teams to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are analyzed in great detail, and being well-prepared can be the key to winning.
Today, there are more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make their moves. In these intense situations, players must act quickly and efficiently, similar to athletes.
At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess masters must be ready for the next challenge every day. Most tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games played daily, and there are competitions all year round. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in 1984 had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game seem strange. However, it also adds to his legacy. If he has returned for the money, he will do well, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a big difference in development. While they can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a lot of money to participate in this work. If that money were given directly to a local community, it could pay for more labor than one volunteer could provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often do not have the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are more interested in improving their own careers. However, these projects can help develop people who may act ethically in their future careers.
B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and more participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help create international social networks among ordinary people. In this way, the benefits can be shared between volunteers and host communities, contributing to the greater good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may only help them gain a global perspective and career advantages, while doing little for the communities that need help.
C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving charity from wealthy Westerners. At its best, it can provide benefits to both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for the exchange of skills and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and commitment to fighting against poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the growing trend of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially in a time when people are skeptical of big governments and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity, which may not truly change the situations of poor communities. While volunteering can be a simple and commendable act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the true understanding of development issues. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from the real problems of global inequality and poverty faced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports that many of us listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five different models.
One model has a 'dual alarm function' that lets you set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. Paul Bridges mentioned that he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.
This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," even though the clock he tested sometimes got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can easily tap it while still half-asleep. **Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small mammal known for its sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All types of hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened, which makes their spines stick out for protection. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in deserts have fewer spines because they have adapted to their environment. These hedgehogs are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using their ability to roll as a last option.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs may stay awake all year.

"Rowing is hard for girls to start because very few schools offer it. Most girls don’t begin until they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Also, coaches often change every year, so there is no stability, and the women's team struggles. But I enjoy it and love being fit, plus there is a good social life."
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world without knowing how big it was! I felt trapped in Britain and wanted freedom. Each walk has been different. The hardest was crossing Australia, where I walked 50 miles a day with very little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men think women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving. When I do well, they often ignore me. Being a woman in racing has its challenges. When I approach a corner, men think they must beat me, so I’ve had many tough moments! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It’s hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are joining racing every year. I love striving for perfection in every lap."
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Sometimes I even fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before a race, and I really push myself during competitions. I often wonder why I do this, and I realize it’s because I feel happier when I stay fit, I would be lazy without this routine, and racing is very social. The prize money is also not as good. However, we have created an International Triathlon Women's Commission to improve this."

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could recognize Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I would not have approached him if my friend hadn’t encouraged me. Nervously, I introduced myself and asked for his signature, and to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of my page and then added a lively drawing below it. His art often reflected real things, so the lines he drew might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.
I thanked him and started a conversation, but since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was limited, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I told Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend what I had. He noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and asked, "Is that all?" He encouraged me to go back and talk to Picasso again, suggesting I could draw his portrait.
With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I decided not to ask if I could draw him, as I thought he might say no. Instead, I stood by the table, set up my pad, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled and made it hard for me to concentrate. He acted out funny faces and gestures, making me laugh. Even though it was challenging, I felt like he was testing my determination to draw him.
Eventually, Picasso relaxed and let me study him closely. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were very expressive. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed to be in his own world, quietly focused on his thoughts.
When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But he insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes and captured my smile with just one lively line.
I thanked Picasso and asked if he could sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he was not going to give me another one! Looking back, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**
Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This article explains the tricks that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.
**A. The Image of Freshness**  
Supermarkets know that customers really want fresh food. To create this feeling, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen to make people think of fresh produce. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Displaying to Advantage**  
The way products are placed in the store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store customers visit the most. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are especially popular with manufacturers. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters. Another strategy is to place related items together, like desserts near ice cream.
**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers have to walk past more expensive items to get to them. Stores also place popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and see other tempting items along the way.
**D. Less Sells More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from the idea of selling many items cheaply. Instead, they create a boutique feel by showing fewer items, making them seem more exclusive. Their success comes from good store design as well as stylish clothing.
**E. Tempting Totals**  
Food shoppers often pay more attention to the total cost of their shopping than to the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items to attract customers. They sometimes sell certain staples at a loss to bring people in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They also get lower prices by buying in large amounts or by promoting products prominently.
**F. The All-Important Price Tag**  
Customers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and notice prices more. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.
**G. Lighting to Effect**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores pay attention to lighting. Chain stores try to use lighting that looks like natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh fruits and vegetables look more appealing.
**H. Walk This Way**  
Many chain stores use different types of carpet to guide customers through the store. One pattern shows the main paths, while another marks sales areas. This strategy, called the "Yellow Brick Road," encourages shoppers to explore, although some may hesitate to leave the main paths. For example, Marks and Spencer uses wood or marble for the main paths to lead customers to the more inviting carpet in sales areas.
**I. In-Store Promotion**  
As you enter a supermarket, you might see large, colorful pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry if you haven't eaten before shopping. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington, 58, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-69, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure*, he called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing techniques, and Robin could teach Chris the basics of sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin paddled to shore to practice climbing.
The climbing route was challenging, but Chris was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. When they reached a steep drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. Robin politely asked if he could climb down using the ropes from his boat, as he was used to using his arms. Chris preferred that he use his legs, but Robin managed to lower himself safely.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin formed a strong friendship. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a big step from their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked for everyone's input first. Although most crew members were hesitant to give advice, it felt good to be part of the decision-making.
Chris found sailing challenging and sometimes boring. He preferred the excitement of crisis moments, but he struggled with spending many days at sea. He is more comfortable on land and not very handy. In contrast, Robin enjoyed sailing and fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless, especially since there were six people on a 32-foot yacht meant for four. On a mountain expedition, there is more space to be alone.
When they reached Greenland and it was Chris's turn to lead the expedition, he felt nervous about being responsible for Robin's safety. There were times when if Robin fell, he could pull Chris down with him. Chris underestimated how hard it would be to climb the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin trusted Chris completely and followed him. When it became too difficult, Chris decided they had to turn back, and Robin accepted this. 
Chris knew Robin was worried about their boat and whether it would be safe in the ice, but Robin still wanted to try climbing the mountain again. The only time they had a serious disagreement was on the yacht on the way home. They were taking turns keeping watch. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his shift, but Robin chose not to wake him, thinking he could handle it alone. Chris had almost fallen asleep the night before and felt that Robin did not trust him. He expressed his feelings, and Robin quickly reassured him that he had misunderstood the situation.
While they enjoyed their trip to Skye, they truly got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. Chris discovered that beneath Robin's tough exterior, he was a kind and sensitive person.

Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner from Britain, visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is located ten miles south of the equator, on a mountain path that leads to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. For the past three years, Nerurkar has trained in Kenya's Central Highlands during the winter, but he had never trained with Kenyan runners before. On his latest trip, he decided to change that. He participated in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race.
Training at high altitude helps runners produce more red blood cells, which improves their ability to carry oxygen. This has contributed to the success of many Kenyan runners. Nerurkar's first race in Africa was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan, but he felt he had performed well.
Nerurkar believes that Kenyan success is not only due to the altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple and relaxed approach to running, and they genuinely enjoy competing. He wanted to learn more about their training methods, so he stayed at the national team camp at St Mark's College, located 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. The camp is basic, with athletes living in shared dormitories with college students.
The daily routine at the camp includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training in the mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. Each day, they run about 40 kilometers, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers. Life at the camp is simple, with minimal preparation for meals. Breakfast includes tea, bread, and boiled eggs, while lunch and dinner consist of ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they often go to bathe in streams from Mount Kenya's glaciers.
By the end of his stay, Nerurkar gained a deeper appreciation for Kenyan runners. Their success cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. He believes that the simplicity of their mountain lifestyle, their hard training, and their passion for running are key reasons for Kenya's dominance in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**
Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem is not just because of the recession; advertising started to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, audiences have become smaller and more specific. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not. This is a major reason why advertising is not working well.
Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you might buy only a few hundred different brands. For big items like cars, you might only buy one every three years, and many people get their cars from their jobs. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. In total, you likely do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year, even when you include all types of products and services.
Now, compare that to the 32,500 brands and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend very little on advertising, we focus on about 9,500 brands that are analyzed. The average person buys only 400 of these brands, which is about 4 percent. This means that a large part of advertising is not effective. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. Most people find that only about 6 percent of the ads are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent of the ads are likely wasted.
You might think you are different and that you are not influenced by advertising, but most people feel the same way. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always some waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. Many ads have shown that they work. Advertisers need to reach a large number of people to find the few who will respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested.
Even with careful targeting, advertisers cannot know exactly who will respond to their ads. For example, a direct mail campaign will never get a 100 percent response rate. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every potential customer they talk to. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all; they could contact those people directly.
Any advertiser who can attract one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is doing well. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be very happy with a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach more than 2 percent of the population is considered very successful, even though that is still a small part of the total population. To improve advertising effectiveness, the messages need to be more focused on specific audiences than ever before.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover visits one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain. This house is located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, which has some interesting features. The first is Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral famous for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 
The Vales have created a home that uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into compost for the garden, and heats the house using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's older buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice it is very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Once inside, you must take off your shoes, as Robert insists on this. The house feels peaceful, especially on a sunny summer day when the windows are closed and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is designed to be airtight. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.
The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called The Autonomous House. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to also avoid using mains water. They designed special toilets that compost waste, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.
Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness." The only medieval feature of the house is its design, with a hall that goes up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay for water, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.
Soon, they will install solar panels in the garden, which will help the house generate more electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will produce extra electricity, enough to charge an electric car in the future. The only heating source is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they rarely use except during very cold weather. 
When Charles visited in February, Robert said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than usual for living areas, but Robert felt comfortable because there were no drafts and everything felt the same temperature. He compares this to how people in the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of their warm clothing. 
The secret to the house's comfort is that it uses simple technology, making it easy to maintain. Most materials were bought from local suppliers and installed by local workers, which kept the building costs low, similar to affordable rental housing. This idea is not popular with commercial building companies, who are resistant to change.

**The Camera Never Lies**
Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational and scientific person. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article where he accepted fairies as magical beings. 
It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the simple trick showed that a basic idea about photography is wrong: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and it always has been able to. 
Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Blacksmiths**
Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were respected like doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were made by talented blacksmiths.
However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron features. In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Still, much of the new work looks similar to past styles, with manufacturers promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks and similar items.
Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and several events are planned to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be starting a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are becoming more aware of the craft. 
Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, twist, and weld it more easily. Dawson explains that these artists now have the tools to express their creativity. About 250 pieces are displayed in the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90 and going up to much higher amounts. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork.
Dawson has created an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and take shape when it’s hot, comparing it to drawing with metal in space. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals that are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, finds it magical because it is soft when hot but becomes hard and unmovable when it cools down.
Ann Catrin Evans creates door knockers and handles from mild steel, inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, and another resembles a Celtic cross. She loves the cold, hard feel of steel and how it seems to last forever. No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used for decorative purposes for many years to come, as long as we can avoid more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**
I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying for me too. 
The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn’t plan to stop smoking, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, and I still do. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.
On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop myself; I’m just here to write." I thought this was a reasonable approach because I enjoyed smoking and found pleasure in it. The counsellor seemed to understand me.
During the session, we were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of quitting began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that was just for me. 
In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had worried that I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing simple things at home on weekend mornings. 
I’ve come to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Dorothy Who?**
Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond with surprise and say something like, "Isn't there already a biography?" they pass my test. 
Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She is important because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. If someone in literature had this achievement, they would be very famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, much like the crystals she studied. Her life shows significant changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the global nature of science.
When I started my research, I wanted to read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested I look for a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of hers and also a Nobel Prize winner. However, when I went to the bookstore, I found that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a very important chemist.
Even scientists sometimes think that biographies about scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and bookstores feel the same way. This idea that scientists are different from artists and writers is a common belief, and it means that only a few famous scientists get biographies.
It is not true that scientists have less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. For example, a well-known geneticist said he would only talk about his work if he was not quoted or photographed, as he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This attitude can make science seem less appealing to young people and can create distrust among the public.
Fortunately, things are changing. Nowadays, scientists often appear in the media in ways that are not just about their research. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real individuals, not just researchers.
The world of publishing is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and often ignored the personal lives of scientists. However, this has changed with books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws, making them more relatable.
Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She was also a devoted mother of three and had a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. While her personal life may not seem directly related to her work, it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.
There is much to learn from her life, but her scientific achievements are also important. Hodgkin's passion for science was central to her success, and explaining this passion is a challenge for biographers. Many readers may not have enough scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without detailed explanations. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.
It is unfortunate that educated people who would feel embarrassed not to know a famous writer or artist often do not recognize the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Farmers whose wells have dried up are increasingly asking for her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she relies only on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.
This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is known as dowsing. There are many theories about how it works, from scientific ideas like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One of the most believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can sense these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.
Recently, during dry years, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with remote cottages or barns that have become holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes over long distances. There are also golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She explains, "You can't drill a well if there is a risk of waste getting into the water supply. The water we find is in cracks of solid rock, and if we bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, there are many minerals, so we have to be careful about iron."
Another important factor is electricity to run the pump, which can be costly if the well is far from power sources. After considering these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It will swing when she is above an area with water.
Once she has identified possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."
Margaret's husband also checks the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill and will keep searching until they find a common agreement.
Margaret Wilkins is not alone in her unique skill; many anthropologists and writers have been intrigued by this mysterious ability. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard to understand how her family could continue to succeed in their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something completely different! We arranged this for four people. Here’s what happened.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 and a mother of two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 
Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her quiet hometown, and she felt nervous. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and told her it happens to everyone.
By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers waiting to get in, and Amanda felt even more nervous. Luckily, the orders were taken automatically, so she didn’t have to remember them all. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she struggled to hear customers over the loud music. She often had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, and Amanda realized how tiring waitressing could be. She thought it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude. Amanda felt relieved to return to her children, as being a mother seemed much easier after her day as a waitress!
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy is 30 and was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She knew Amanda's daughters could be cheeky, but she thought she could handle it. 
After Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she was wrong! Amanda reminded her that she still had to clean the house and do laundry. 
At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. When she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and screamed loudly while playing. Cindy thought they would tire out, but they had more energy than she expected! After a lot of effort, she finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun continued. The girls kept asking for water, just to come downstairs and watch TV. Cindy realized how tiring it is to take care of two small children. She had no time for herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. Still, she enjoyed the day.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a primary school teacher. 
On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, but on this day, she got to sleep in until 7 am. She was nervous about how to dress for school, so she tried to blend in. At assembly, she hoped no one would notice her. 
In class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from Rosemary's school days. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. After lunch, she attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Although teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she prefers farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary arrived at Rosemary's farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm is large, with many cows and sheep. 
Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice cream. She had to resist eating the treats! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not checked daily, they can die. After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year!
Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children, as animals don’t talk back. She realized that farming is not as easy as it seems. The work is constant, and it’s hard to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of vacation each year. Farming may look romantic, but the reality is very different, with an unpredictable income and dependence on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who did not play music in a small town in southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings are introducing new music, including concertos by forgotten composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces. When you meet him, he looks younger than his age, with a bright and friendly personality, just like the sound of the trumpet.
Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls. He also had a feature on television about his work and growth, filmed in both London and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his music career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother found the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra and convinced him to give her son lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, quickly recognized Hakan's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a passionate teacher from the beginning, someone who loved the trumpet and sought out players from around the world.
Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, he had a special ability to find the right balance and connect with the instrument. He notes that even as a child, his unique sound was already noticeable, which was the first thing he developed.
Unlike John Wallace, another famous trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a trumpet player and allowed him to practice as much as he wanted. At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud also believed that playing in an orchestra was not as fulfilling as being a soloist.
Hardenberger knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special talent for connecting with the audience. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but made it to the second. Fortunately, he already knew most of the pieces for that round too. When he reached the final, he faced a concerto that had intimidated him before. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even if he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.
Hardenberger's honest view of his work might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids trying to explain what makes his communication with the audience special, saying that doing so might ruin it. He believes the power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a powerful tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures a mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her child.

He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

Aurora's approach to life is a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, and Rosie helps her navigate her relationships with suitors and friends.
